description: A solemn granite and marble mausoleum housing the embalmed body of Vietnam's revolutionary leader Ho Chi Minh, built from 1973-1975 in Ba Dinh Square where he declared independence on September 2, 1945. Inspired by Lenin's Tomb but adapted to Vietnamese customs, the 21.6-meter-high structure stands as the nation's most iconic memorial.
highlights: Glass case displaying Ho Chi Minh's embalmed body in khaki outfit
Ba Dinh Square - historic site of the 1945 Declaration of Independence
Surrounding gardens with 250 plant species from across Vietnam
Nearby One Pillar Pagoda on the complex grounds
Ho Chi Minh Museum with extensive artifact collection
tips: Open Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday, Sunday only
Closed annually September-November for body maintenance
Arrive early morning to avoid long queues
Dress formally - no shorts, mini-skirts, sleeveless shirts, or tank tops
All cameras, mobile phones, and day packs must be checked before entry
Maintain complete silence inside the mausoleum
No food, drinks, or photography allowed
Watch the 6am flag ceremony for full experience
vibe: A place of profound reverence and national pride, the mausoleum commands respect through its imposing architecture and strict protocols. Long queues of Vietnamese citizens wait patiently to pay respects to Uncle Ho, whose modest khaki outfit and rubber sandals contrast with the grand monument. The atmosphere is solemn and moving, where Vietnam's revolutionary past meets present-day devotion in dignified silence.
